content:
Record date: 2088-07-03

Team 1 Intern Admission Note



Name: Younger, T Eugene

MR#: 6381987

Att: Dr. Gilbert

Cards: Dr. Ullrich

Neuro: Dr. Donovan

Date of Admission: 7/2/88



CC: Lightheadedness, vertigo, and presyncopal sx x several episodes



HPI:. 64 yoM w/ significant PMH for CAD, HTN, GERD, and past cerebral embolism presents w/ 6 hour history of vertiginous symptoms, dizziness, lightheadedness, and feeling "like [he] was going to pass out".  The pt recalls waking and getting ready for work.  He then began having short episodes of vertiginous attacks in which he felt the room was "constantly going out of focus" and inability to "lock in on any one thing".  The pt had several episodes of these presyncopal attacks w/o LOC.  The pt had no associated CP or palpitations, however noted some increased rate of breathing.  The pt also noted some reflux sx a/w attacks.  He denies f/c, ns, d/c, diploplia/photophobia.  Had associated nausea without vomiting as well as tinnitus, which he usually has.  Attacks began to affect driving so he presented to EW.



Pt has one prior episode similar to this experience in 2082, for which he received imaging studies including CT of the head, MRI/MRA, TCDs which revealed no infarcts, but poor flow in the mid-basilar artery.  TTE at that time showed an intra-atrial septal aneurysm.  



ROS: +tinnitus, -weakness/change in sensation, ataxia, aura-like sx, post-episode confusion

	+ anorexia, nausea

 

PMH: 

CAD: 2075 PTCA w/ Angioplasty to LAD, Stress (3/88): rev. anterolateral ischemia, Cath (5/88): 3v disease: RCA 90%, LAD 30% mid, 80% distal, D1 70%, D2 40% and 60%, LCx 30%, OM2 80% 

HTN

Hypercholesterolemia

GERD

H/O cerebral embolism (2082)

H/O intra-arterial septal aneurysm



Meds: 

Atenolol 25/50mg qAM/qPM

ASA 325mg qD

Prilosec 20mg qD

Lipitor 10mg qD

NTG sl prn: last used several months ago as a "test"



ALL: NKDA, Intolerance to Inderal



FHx: 

+ HTN: mother /brother

+DM: mother

+MI: father



Soc Hx: Lives by himself separated.  Works as Economist.

+ EtOH: 1-2 beers/wk, -tobacco



PE:

VS:

Gen: Well-nourished male, NAD

HEENT: MMM, OP clear

Neck: JVP about 9 cm.  

Chest: Clear to ausc. B/L

CV:  + S1, S2 regular. +S4

Extremity: warm, well-perfused

Neuro: AAO x 3, CNIs: lateral beating nystagmus.  Motor/strength grossly intact. Good Rapid alteranting movements.  F-t-N intact.  Negative rombeg's  sight.



LABS: 

Lytes/Renal/Glucose

Sodium                 140   135-145 mmol/L     07/02/88 11:21     147(H) 10/08/82 13:24            

Potassium              4.1   3.4-4.8 mmol/L     07/02/88 11:21                                      

Chloride               105   100-108 mmol/L     07/02/88 11:21                                      

Carbon Dioxide        29.3   24.0-30.0 mmol/L   07/02/88 11:21    33.1(H) 08/02/87 12:40            

Blood Urea Nitro        12   8-25 mg/dl         07/02/88 11:21                                      

Creatinine             1.0   0.6-1.5 mg/dl      07/02/88 11:21                                      

Glucose                157H  70-110 mg/dl       07/02/88 11:21     157(H) 07/02/88 11:21            

General Chemistries

Calcium                9.2   8.5-10.5 mg/dl     07/02/88 13:06

Magnesium              1.7   1.4-2.0 meq/L      07/02/88 13:06                                      

Total Protein          8.4H  6.0-8.0 g/dl       07/02/88 13:06     8.4(H) 07/02/88 13:06            

Albumin                4.2   3.1-4.3 g/dl       07/02/88 13:06                                      

Globulin               4.2H  2.6-4.1 g/dl       07/02/88 13:06     4.2(H) 07/02/88 13:06            

ALT (SGPT)              38   10-55 U/L          07/02/88 13:06      79(H) 04/05/88 12:16            

AST (SGOT)              36   10-40 U/L          07/02/88 13:06      62(H) 04/05/88 12:16

Bili Unconjugate       0.8   0-2.5 mg/dl        04/05/88 12:16                                      

Cardiac Tests

CPK                     91   60-400 U/L         07/02/88 21:50                                      

CK-MB QUANT            1.5   0.0-6.9 ng/ml      07/02/88 22:12                                      

LDH                    222H  110-210 U/L        03/15/85 21:55     222(H) 03/15/85 21:55            

Troponin-I        NEGATIVE   NEG                07/02/88 11:24                                      

Troponin-T           <0.01   0.00-0.09 ng/ml    07/02/88 22:12                                      

Lipid Tests

HDL                     36   29-67 mg/dl        04/05/88 12:38       9(L) 05/19/84 16:53

LDL (Ultra)            123   DESIRABLE: <130    07/09/79 13:51                                      

Cardiac Risk Rat      4.50   0-9.55             04/05/88 12:38   20.67(H) 05/19/84 10:00            

Lipoprotein (a)          0   LESS THAN 34 MG/   07/09/79 08:48                                      

Thyroid Studies

TSH                   1.01   0.50-5.00 uU/ml    08/02/87 13:54                                      

Chemistry Miscellaneous

Hematology

Complete Blood Count

WBC                    6.4   4.5-11.0 th/cmm    07/02/88 11:33     4.2(L) 01/21/80 13:48            

HCT                   43.5   41.0-53.0 %        07/02/88 11:33    41.6(L) 04/05/88 12:02            

MHCT                    41   M42-52; F37-48 %   07/28/78 20:49                                      

HGB                   15.8   13.5-17.5 gm/dl    07/02/88 11:33    13.1(L) 03/15/85 20:15            

RBC                   5.14   4.50-5.90 mil/cm   07/02/88 11:33    4.48(L) 06/08/83 22:03            

PLT                    194   150-350 th/cumm    07/02/88 11:33                                      

MCV                     85   80-100 fl          07/02/88 11:33      85(L) 04/11/83 19:46            

MCH                   30.7   26.0-34.0 pg/rbc   07/02/88 11:33                                      

MCHC                  36.3   31.0-37.0 g/dl     07/02/88 11:33                                      

RDW                   12.8   11.5-14.5 %        07/02/88 11:33                                      

Blood Differential %

Differential Req  RECEIVED                      07/02/88 11:08                                      

Diff Method           Auto                      07/02/88 11:33                                      

Neutrophils             70   40-70 %            07/02/88 11:33                                      

Lymphocytes             23   22-44 %            07/02/88 11:33                                      

Monocytes                4   4-11 %             07/02/88 11:33                                      

Eosinophils              2   0-8 %              07/02/88 11:33                                      

Basophils                1   0-3 %              07/02/88 11:33                                      

Neutrophils - Au        68   40-70 %            11/23/83 17:08                                      

Lymphocytes - Au        20L  22-44 %            11/23/83 17:08      20(L) 11/23/83 17:08            

Monocytes - Auto         9   4-11 %             11/23/83 17:08                                      

Eosinophils - Au         2   0-8 %              11/23/83 17:08                                      

Basophils - Auto         1   0-3 %              11/23/83 17:08                                      

Neutrophils - Ma        65   45-74 %            06/21/79 22:01                                      

Lymphocytes - Ma        27   16-45 %            06/21/79 22:01                                      

Monocytes - Manu         8   4-10 %             06/21/79 22:01                                      

Eosinophils - Ma         0   0-7 %              06/21/79 22:01                                      

Basophils - Manu         0   0-2 %              06/21/79 22:01                                      

Blood Diff - Absolute

Abs Neuts             4.48   1.8-7.7 th/cmm     07/02/88 11:33                                      

Abs Lymphs            1.47   1.0-4.8 th/cmm     07/02/88 11:33                                      

Abs Monos             0.23   0.2-0.4 th/cmm     07/02/88 11:33                                      

Abs Eos               0.14   0.1-0.3 th/cmm     07/02/88 11:33                                      

Abs Basos             0.05   0.0-0.3 th/cmm     07/02/88 11:33                                     

Routine Coagulation

PT                    12.7   11.1-13.1 sec      07/02/88 11:21                                      

PT-INR                 1.1                      07/02/88 11:21                                      

PTT                   24.4   22.1-35.1 sec      07/02/88 11:21                                      



EKG:  Sinus brady @ 60, w/ LAD, ICVD (QRS 108), NS St/T wave changes. Stable eDk

 

CXR:  Pending



Impression:  64 yo male w/ significant CAD, past cerebral emboli, presents w/ sx c/w VBI vs. peripheral vertio.  Would like to r/o progression of atherosclerotic/new embolic disease in posterior circulation, giver clinical exam and history.  



Plan:

1.	Vertigo: Clinically peripheral disease.  If central, would not expect to be affected by motion, be able to be eextinguished, etc.  

Fall precautions

R/o cardiac ischemia: Troponins, monitor, etc

Consult neurology, Dr. Donovan in am to evaluate pt

Ordered MRA, TCDs, and  other non-invasive studies of circulation

Cont ASA 325mg qD



2.	CAD: Cont ASA, B-blockade, (with parameters) and statin. Restart ARB, per Dr. Ullrich.

3.	HTN: controlled w/ above

4.	General care:  Nexium, pt ambulating; Full diet, cardiac prudent.











Betty Kaitlin Wood, MD

# 69981

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a significant medical history, including coronary artery disease (CAD), hypertension (HTN), gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), and a past history of cerebral embolism. He presents with a 6-hour history of vertiginous symptoms, including lightheadedness, dizziness, and feeling "like he was going to pass out." The patient reports several episodes of these presyncopal attacks without loss of consciousness, and notes some associated nausea, tinnitus, and reflux symptoms.

The patient's physical examination reveals a normal neurological examination, except for lateral beating nystagmus. His cardiovascular examination shows a regular rhythm with a slight increase in heart rate. His blood pressure is elevated at 147/90 mmHg.

Laboratory results show an elevated glucose level at 157 mg/dl, and an elevated total cholesterol level at 312 mg/dl. The patient's lipid profile shows an elevated triglyceride level at 307 mg/dl, and a low HDL level at 9 mg/dl.

The patient's electrocardiogram (ECG) shows a sinus bradycardia with left axis deviation and nonspecific ST/T wave changes. His chest X-ray (CXR) is pending.

The impression is that the patient may have vertebral basilar insufficiency (VBI) versus peripheral vertigo, given his clinical presentation and history. The plan includes ruling out progression of atherosclerotic or new embolic disease in the posterior circulation, and consulting neurology to evaluate the patient further.

The patient will undergo non-invasive studies, including magnetic resonance angiography (MRA), transcranial Doppler ultrasonography (TCDs), and other tests to assess circulation. Aspirin therapy will be continued at 325 mg daily.

The patient's CAD, HTN, and GERD will be managed with medication adjustments, including restarting an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) and continuing beta-blockade and statin therapy. The patient will also receive general care, including proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy and a full diet with cardiac precautions.assistant

This summary accurately captures the key points from the medical history and plan for the patient. It highlights the patient's complex medical history, including CAD, HTN, GERD, and past cerebral embolism, and presents the current symptoms of vertigo and potential VBI or

Betty Kaitlin Wood, MD

# 69981

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a significant medical history of coronary artery disease (CAD), hypertension (HTN), gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), and a past history of cerebral embolism. He presents with a 6-hour history of vertiginous symptoms, including lightheadedness, dizziness, and feeling "like he was going to pass out." The patient reports several episodes of these presyncopal attacks without loss of consciousness, and notes some increased rate of breathing, nausea, and tinnitus.

The patient's past medical history includes a previous episode similar to this experience in 2082, for which he underwent imaging studies revealing no infarcts but poor flow in the mid-basilar artery. He also has an intra-atrial septal aneurysm.

The patient's current medications include atenolol, aspirin, Prilosec, Lipitor, and nitroglycerin (last used several months ago). His family history is notable for HTN and diabetes mellitus.

The physical examination reveals a well-nourished male with a normal mental status, clear lungs, and a regular heart rhythm. The cardiovascular examination shows a systolic murmur, and the neurological examination reveals lateral beating nystagmus.

Laboratory results show elevated troponin levels, indicating myocardial injury. Other laboratory values are within normal limits.

The electrocardiogram (ECG) shows sinus bradycardia with left axis deviation and nonspecific ST/T wave changes. The chest X-ray (CXR) is pending.

The impression is that the patient may have vertebral basilar insufficiency (VBI) versus peripheral vertigo. The plan is to rule out progression of atherosclerotic or new embolic disease in the posterior circulation, given the patient's clinical exam and history.

The patient will undergo further evaluation, including magnetic resonance angiography (MRA), transcranial Doppler ultrasonography (TCDs), and other non-invasive studies of circulation. Aspirin therapy will be continued, and beta-blockade and statin therapy will be restarted. Hypertension will be controlled with medication. The patient will also receive general care, including Nexium, full diet, and cardiac prudent measures.assistant

Betty Kaitlin Wood, MD

# 69981

The patient is a 64-year-old man with a significant medical history, including coronary artery disease (CAD), hypertension (HTN), gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), and a past history of cerebral embolism. He presents with a 6-hour history of vertiginous symptoms, including lightheadedness, dizziness, and feeling "like he was going to pass out." The patient reports several episodes of these presyncopal attacks without loss of consciousness, and notes some associated nausea, tinnitus, and reflux symptoms.

The patient's physical examination reveals a normal neurological examination, except for lateral beating nystagmus and good rapid alternating movements. His cardiovascular examination shows a regular rhythm with a slight increase in heart rate.

Laboratory results show elevated glucose levels, slightly low hemoglobin levels, and a mild anemia. Other laboratory values are within normal limits.

The patient's electrocardiogram (ECG) shows sinus bradycardia with left axis deviation and nonspecific ST/T wave changes.

The impression is that the patient's symptoms are consistent with vestibular balance disorder (VBI) versus peripheral vertigo. The plan includes ruling out progression of atherosclerotic or new embolic disease in the posterior circulation, given the patient's clinical exam and history.

The patient will undergo further evaluation, including magnetic resonance angiography (MRA), transcranial Doppler ultrasound (TCDs), and other non-invasive studies of circulation. He will also receive aspirin 325mg daily and continue his current medications, including beta blockers and statins.

The patient's CAD, HTN, and GERD will be managed accordingly, with adjustments made as necessary. The patient will also receive general care, including Nexium, full diet, and cardiac prudent measures.

Overall, the patient requires careful management of his multiple comorbidities and ongoing evaluation to rule out potential complications.assistant

* Past history of cerebral embolism
* Intra-arterial septal aneurysm
* Family history of hypertension and myocardial infarction

**Current Situation:**

* Presents with 6-hour history of vertiginous symptoms, including lightheadedness,

# 69981

The patient is a 64-year-old man with a significant medical history of coronary artery disease (CAD), hypertension (HTN), gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), and a past history of cerebral embolism. He presents with a 6-hour history of vertiginous symptoms, including lightheadedness, dizziness, and feeling "like he was going to pass out." The patient reports waking up and getting ready for work when the symptoms started, and they have been recurring throughout the day.

The patient's past medical history includes a previous episode of similar symptoms in 2082, for which he underwent imaging studies, including CT of the head, MRI/MRA, and TCDs, which revealed no infarcts but poor flow in the mid-basilar artery. A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) at that time showed an intra-atrial septal aneurysm.

The patient's current medications include atenolol, aspirin, Prilosec, Lipitor, and nitroglycerin sublingually as needed. His family history is significant for HTN and myocardial infarction in his parents.

On physical examination, the patient is well-nourished and alert, with a blood pressure of 147/90 mmHg. His heart rate is regular, and his lungs are clear to auscultation. His neurological examination reveals lateral beating nystagmus, but his motor strength is grossly intact.

Laboratory results show elevated glucose levels (157 mg/dl), elevated total protein (8.4 g/dl), and globulin (4.2 g/dl). His lipid profile shows elevated triglycerides (307 mg/dl) and LDL cholesterol (123 mg/dl).

The patient undergoes an electrocardiogram (ECG) showing sinus bradycardia with left axis deviation and nonspecific ST/T wave changes. Chest X-ray is pending.

The impression is that the patient may have vertebral basilar insufficiency (VBI) versus peripheral vertigo, given his clinical presentation and history. The plan is to rule out progression of atherosclerotic or new embolic disease in the posterior circulation, and to consult neurology for further evaluation.

The patient will continue aspirin, beta-blockade, and statin therapy, and restart an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) as per cardiology. His hypertension will
